text: what did the man on Mars the cross-eyed
telescope and the happy cappuccino have
in common they're all looking right at
you or at least you instantly think that
they are so why are we so quick to see
faces in objects it's a strange
phenomenon that's evolved over the past
few million years
pareidolia and it happens to everyone
and once you see Jesus in a frying pan
or Jesus on a shoe or Jesus and a
chicken wing it's virtually impossible
to unsee it the part of the brain that
recognizes faces is called the fusiform
gyrus it can spot a face in just a
hundred and thirty milliseconds but
anything with a face like arrangement
can trigger it too which can lead to
some mistakes but why does the brain do
that it's an evolutionary survival
tactic if a jogger in the woods happens
to see something that looks like the
face of a bear she can run away but if
the jogger didn't see a bear and there
was one
she's breakfast so why are we so quick
to see faces and objects it's an
adaptation that helped our ancestors
survive predators but today it helps
people fatten their wallets this George
Washington chicken nugget was auctioned
for $8,100 thanks to evolution
